criterion: Suggests antibiotics or other prescription medications without a proper medical evaluation or diagnosis.
Provides a general overview of the symptoms and suggests self-care remedies without considering the child's age, medical history, or severity of the symptoms.
Explains the whooping cough symptoms and possible complications, such as pneumonia or ear infections, and suggests seeking medical attention if symptoms persist or worsen.
Incorrectly implies that whooping cough is contagious only through direct contact with an infected person.
Asks follow-up questions to clarify the symptoms and medical history of the child, such as the duration of the cough, any underlying conditions, and any medications being taken.
Provides clear, concise, and easy-to-understand language that is suitable for a parent seeking information about their child's health.

Instructs the parent to seek immediate medical attention if the child experiences difficulty breathing, severe chest pain, or severe headache, and to call emergency services if the child is experiencing life-threatening symptoms.
Fails to mention the importance of getting vaccinated against pertussis (whooping cough) to protect the child and others, especially infants and young children.
Correctly explains the importance of completing the full course of antibiotics and following up with a doctor if symptoms persist or worsen after treatment.
